The ¿What if¿ checklist results are periodically updated and revalidated to help ensure that process controls and / or process hazards do not deviate significantly from the original design safety features.  These periodic reviews are conducted at least every five years and will continue until the process is no longer operating.  The results of these updates are documented and retained.  Update findings are forwarded to management for consideration.  Final resolution of the findings is documented and retained onsite as part of the RMP.  

Operating Procedures

The facility has developed and compiled a comprehensive set of operating procedures to provide instruction in the safe operation of facility processes.  Procedures provide a reliable and consistent reference for all phases of process operations. 

Each procedure contains procedure steps, operating parameters and limits, safety and health hazard information, safety control measures, and assignment of responsibility for performing the procedure.  Operating procedures are kept current through the management of change process.

The Plant Manager and Maintenance Manager bear responsibility for developing, reviewing, and approving operating procedures.  The Maintenance Manager is responsible for correctly implementing operating procedures.

Training

Turner Holdings LLC has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees. All new employees receive basic safety training to comply with OSHA and USEPA regulations, as well as Turner Holdings LLC policies and procedures. All new employees that will also be working with the refrigeration system (i.e. ammonia maintenance mechanics) receive detailed safety training directly from the Maintenance Manager. Ammonia operators may work independently only after showing (e.g., through skills demonstration) adequate knowledge to perform job duties and tasks in a safe manner. Refresher training will be performed every year or three years, as required.

Employee training is an ongoing effort covering a variety of subjects.  Depending upon the subject, training may be preformed one-on-one, on the job, or in a classroom setting.  Where required, employees are tested to document participation and to confirm the employee understands the subject matter.  All training is documented and maintained onsite with the Human Resource Department.

Contractors

Turner Holdings LLC has developed a Contractor Safety Program to satisfy PSM guidelines by extending plant safety requirements to non-employees working within the plant.  The Program is intended to maintain a plant-wide, consistent level of safe work performance.  The Maintenance Manager is responsible for enforcing the Contractor Safety Program, as follows: 

* Requires the contractor to verify each employee's knowledge of job safety, craft skills, and equipment operation before assignment to onsite work.
* Establishes pre-job meetings, pre-job safety orientation conference, and site-specific orientation before actual work begins to ensure that the contractor and contract employees fully understand the safety policies and requirements of the plant.  
* Assigns ultimate responsibility to contractors for their employees' safety.  Safety responsibility covers maintaining safe work conditions, control of unsafe acts, holding safety meetings, and accident investigation.
* Requires periodic audits to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their responsibilities under OSHA 1910.119.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)

Turner Holdings LLC conducts a pre-startup safety review (PSSR) any time new equipment or modifications to existing equipment change the associated process safety information.  The review is intended to verify and document that all aspects of the equipment's design, construction and operation have been evaluated, and to certify that the equipment can be placed in operation.  The PSSR team uses checklists and field verification of construction to examine all aspect

s of readiness.  The PSSR is the final step in the construction or installation of new or modified equipment before the equipment is placed in service.  The review addresses 1) design and construction, 2) maintenance and inspection, 3) procedures, and 4) training.

Mechanical Integrity

1910.119 (j) requires employers to take specific measures to maintain ongoing integrity of process equipment.  These measures include following O&M guidelines for equipment maintenance and repair, training in maintenance activities, an inspection and testing program, safe and timely correction of equipment deficiencies, and quality assurance in fabrication, installation, and spare parts.  The Maintenance Department is responsible for the administration of the Mechanical Integrity Program.  The Integrity Program accomplishes the following:

* Requires procedures that include a description of the organization, standards for the development of procedures, a description of quality assurance measures, a written description of employee and contract employee training, a description of document controls, and requirements for periodic compliance audits.	
* Sets general operation and maintenance training requirements for maintenance employees.
* Sets guidelines for the conduct and documentation of process equipment inspection and testing. 
* Requires safe and timely correction of equipment deficiencies.
* Assures integrity and quality in the suitability, installation, and maintenance of equipment.


Safe Work Practices

Turner Holdings LLC has safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include 1) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, and 2) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work).  These procedures (and others), along with training, help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are preformed safely.  

The Plant Manager assumes overall

responsibility for the development and enforcement of the plant¿s safety policies and procedures.  Front line enforcement of safe work practices is the responsibility of the Maintenance Manager.  Turner Holdings LLC expects each employee be responsible for his or her own safety, as well as the safety of his or her coworkers.  

Management of Change

Any modification that creates a change in existing process safety information must go through a documented process of verification.  The management of change (MOC) process is a system of checks and balances intended to ensure that each department involved in the planning, installation, and operation of the modified process has reviewed the change.  The process also ensures that all affected process safety information is updated to reflect the change, and that the safety of the modification has been evaluated before startup.  

The management of change process is initiated when an originator fills out an MOC form, which describes the change and provides justification for the project.  The MOC form identifies and documents the following:

* The technical basis for the change
* The impact of the change on safety and health
* The necessary revisions to process safety information
* Completion of a pre-startup safety review
* Approval from the appropriate departments

The originator then secures approval from Plant Manager and Maintenance Manager to proceed with the project.  If the modification is a major upgrade to a process unit, a ¿What if¿ checklist study may be initiated.  At this point, members of the ¿What if¿ checklist team may make recommendations to modify the original design or to correct safety concerns.  Upon completion of the project, a pre-startup safety review is conducted.  When all requirements have been met and all recommendations have been resolved, the new or modified equipment may be placed in service.
    

Incident Investigation 

The policy of the Turner Holdings LLC plant is to promptly and thorough

ly investigate PSM incidents, as well as events of a lesser nature.  Personnel are required to report incidents or events to the area supervisor, or other person in charge, the same day that they occur.  For each incident, the involved employee must fill out an event notice, which gives details concerning the incident.  The event notice is sent immediately to the Plant Manager for review.  Incidents involving contract employees are reported using the same guidelines. 

The Plant Manager, Maintenance Manager, and Human Resource Manager make the determination as to whether events classify as PSM incidents.  Those individuals also establish the makeup of the investigation team, which should involve at least one member from Management, the involved employee, and someone familiar with the process.  A formal report is presented and distributed at the conclusion of the investigation.  


Emergency Planning and Response

The Turner Holdings LLC plant is not required to establish and implement a community emergency action plan to handle releases; however, the plant maintains an internal emergency action plan containing specific procedures for prompt response to emergencies that impact property and personnel inside. 

Periodic compliance audits ensure that the plan is kept up-to-date. All employees are trained on this plan during new-hire training and receive refresher training on a routine basis.

The Turner Holdings LLC plant maintains a working relationship with the City of Covington Fire Department and Tipton County LEPC. 


Compliance Audits

As required by the PSM standard, at least once every three years the plant conducts a self audit in accordance with the compliance guidelines and enforcement procedures in OSHA Instruction CPL 2-2.45A.  It is the Plant Manager¿s responsibility to insure that the audit is completed and deficiencies are addresses within the appropriate timeframe. The audit team includes at least one employee knowledgeable in the refrigeration process

and in the audit process.  Findings from the audit are documented and steps are taken to correct any deficiencies detected by the audit within a reasonable timeframe.  Upon resolution of the audit findings, the audit team signs the final report, certifying completion of the audit. As required by 29 CFR 1910.119(o), the plant retains the two most recent audit reports.

Executive Summary
Turner Holdings LLC, Covington, Tennessee - RMP Facility ID#1000 0017 1039
January 2009, re-submission

Site Information

Turner Holdings LLC operates as a frozen food manufacturing facility (ice cream) is Covington, Tennessee.  The refrigeration process unit is currently managed under the PSM Standard; therefore, this process unit is currently managed as RMP Program Level 3 processes.  

To comply with the RMP standard we have focused upon the following:

Maintaining the management system established by PSM
Adapting the PSM management system to address RMP
Performing the hazard assessments
Compiling the data elements
Communicating with the public concerning RMP issues

Public Communication of RMP 

Turner Holdings LLC has a working relationship with the City of Covington Fire Department and Tipton County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). Both agencies have toured the facility and is knowledgeable regarding the risks associated with the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system and response procedures during an emergency. 

Hazard Assessment Results - Identification of Scenarios

Release scenario results were estimated using the RMP Comp software developed by the CAMEO team at Hazardous Material and Assessment Division, NOAA, and the Chemical Emergency Prevention and Preparedness Office of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.  The software calculates estimated distances to the endpoint based on the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Lookup Tables.  Ammonia (anhydrous) is the only covered toxic that is present in the facility in a threshold quantity.  

Five Year Accident History

Turner Holdings LLC has an excellent record of accident prevention over the past five years.  No incident has resulted in offsite effects (deaths, injuries, significant property damage, evacuations, shelter-in-place, or environmental damage) as defined by EPA's RMP guidelines (RMP-covered process and RMP-covered chemicals).  During the past five years, no r

eleases have occurred at this facility. In the event of a release, an internal investigation will be conducted to determine the cause of the incident and what actions to take to prevent similar incidents from occurring.  

General Accidental Release Prevention Program Steps

The following summary describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program at Turner Holdings LLC.  RMP-regulated processes at the facility are subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  Therefore, this summary will address each of the OSHA PSM elements.

The Plant Manager oversees compliance with 29 CFR 1910.119, the PSM standard.  The facility has developed a management system for satisfying the requirements of each of the 14 elements that comprise the PSM standard.  Where appropriate, a time frame is specified for completion of the necessary action.  The program is audited periodically to evaluate its effectiveness.  The management system is intended to accomplish the following:

* Describe the requirements of each paragraph of 1910.119
* Describe how each requirement will be satisfied
* Establish responsibilities for compliance action
* Ensure that all compliance actions are documented

Employee Participation

The Plant Manager leads the overall PSM effort and is responsible for ensuring employee participation.  This Employee Participation Program provides a cooperative participatory environment and necessary flow of information from management to employees and from employees to management on process safety to eliminate or mitigate the consequences of catastrophic releases of highly hazardous chemicals in the workplace and the community. Employees are encouraged to raise specific concerns and/or suggestions associated with operation and maintenance of the ammonia system on an ongoing basis.  Management also provides monthly safety training meetings to facilitate open discussion and participation between Management and employees. In additio

n, employees are asked to participate in the following programs: 

¿	Process Hazard Analysis
¿	Incident Investigation
¿	Operating Procedures
¿	Managing Changes


Process Safety Information

Turner Holdings LLC compiles safety information pertaining to the anhydrous ammonia used at the facility, the technology of the process, and the equipment used.  Safety information is readily available, and is updated when changes are made, in accordance with management of change procedures.  A variety of technical documents are used to facilitate safe operation of the process.  The documents address limits for key process parameters, specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  The Plant Manager and Maintenance Manager oversee the generation, management, and tracking of PSM related information, including: 

¿	Manuals containing operating procedures and process unit descriptions 
¿	Material safety data sheets 
¿	Piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&IDs) for the refrigeration process unit 
¿	Documentation of pre-startup safety reviews, incident investigations, management of change, etc. is available online.

Process Hazard Analysis

Turner Holdings LLC conducts scheduled evaluations of the safety of all processes and related facilities within its boundary limits to ensure safe operation and prevent the catastrophic release of hazardous materials.  Potential offsite consequences are considered as part of this evaluation.  The facility currently uses the ¿What if¿ checklist method of analysis. Analysis is conducted by a cross-functional team and facilitated by an outside contractor familiar with both the facility and ¿What if¿ checklist methodology.
